Body:
There are several facts speaking against this theory:

  1. Phonetic corresponences between Tibetan and Chinese words which are not borrowings from either of the related languages.

  2. The way the Chinese loan words are pronounced in neighbouring languages of the area which are not related to Chinese (e.g. Korean, Japanese or Vietnamese). Theuy demonstrate regular phonetic correspondances between lexical items of Chinese/accepting languages.

  3. The correspondance between the ancient Japanese scripts (e.g. that of Manyoushyuu) and the corresponding Chinese characters.

  4. Chinese vocabulary items which are spelled... OK, which are written differently yet cover the close semantical fields. The difference implies, either simultaneously or per criterium: initial / tone / medial / final. Some regular corresponences between criteria can be observed.

  5. Tonality of the language and tone sandhis.

  6. Phonetics (that is, the items having phonetical meaning as well) in Chinese writing system.
